Authors:
Rui Zhang, Gregory M Mueller, Fei Xiao Shi, Pei-Gui Liu,
Andrew W. Wilson
Title:
Dilemmatic calibration of the evolutionary history of
ectomycorrhizal genus Suillus revealed by multigene phylogeny and
ancestral host association analyses
Keywords:
host specificity, ectomycorrhizal fungiplant symbioses,
host shifts, fossil calibration
Abstract:
 Suillus has exceptional high host specificity among
genera of Ectomycorrhizal (EM) fungi. With a few exceptions, Suillus
species associate exclusively with Pinus, Larix, and Pseudotsuga.
However, the phylogenetic distribution and geological ages of these host
associations are largely unknown.  We inferred the first multigene
phylogeny of Suillus that includes 61 species using sequences from 28S,
TEF1, RPB1 and RPB2. Ancestral host associations were reconstructed
using BAYESTRAITS and S-DIVA referring from extant host associations
compiled from literatures, field observations and environmental samples.
Divergence dates using fossil calibration were estimated in BEAST.  We
confirmed that ancestral Suillus species are associated with Larix, one
monophyletic clade switched host to Pinus, and another clade to
Pseudotsuga. So the only Ectomycorrhizal fossil from Pinus root
identified as Suillus or Rhizopogon would have at least two phylogenetic
positions. The fossil could either be regarded as Suillus in the derived
SuillusPinus clade or as the common ancestor of Suillus and Rhizopogon.
Under the former scenario, genus Suillus originated in the upper
Cretaceous (90Ma) and shifted hosts to Pinus and Pseudotsuga in early
Eocene. Or Suillus originated in early Eocene and shifted hosts in early
Oligocene.  Comparison of the ancestral hosts of Suillus and the
divergence dates of Pinaceae gave more supports for the recent
divergence of the SuillusPinus clade and the fossil is less likely to be
Suillus. However, the exact position of the ectomycorrhizal fossil is
still unknown.
